questions.explanation: Ans. D. Vancomycin

questions.text: Adrenaline acting via beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation whereas histamine acting through H1 receptors cause bronchoconstriction. Which type of antagonism it is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Physiological Antagonism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • A) Pharmacological Antagonism: This term generally refers to one drug reducing the effectiveness of another drug, typically through receptor competition or a similar mechanism at the molecular level. Since adrenaline and histamine act on different receptors to produce opposite physiological effects, this option is not correct.
  • • B) Chemical Antagonism: This occurs when one drug directly reacts with another to neutralize its effects e.g. antacids neutralize gastric acid and protamine neutralize heparin. There is no direct chemical reaction between adrenaline and histamine, making this option incorrect.
  • • C) Physical Antagonism: This would imply that the drugs physically interfere with each other e.g. charcoal adbsorbs many drugs and is used in drug poisoning.
  • • D) Physiological Antagonism: This is the correct answer. Physiological antagonism occurs when two drugs produce opposite effects in the same physiological system. Adrenaline causes bronchodilation via beta-2 receptors, while histamine causes bronchoconstriction via H1 receptors. These drugs act on different receptor types but have opposite effects on the same physiological system, namely the bronchial smooth muscle.

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with pinpoint pupil, diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation and garlic dour. on examination there is bradycardia and BP is 80/60 mm Hg pulse rate is 56/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 52 U/mL. Which of the following is antidote for treatment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Atropine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • A) Pralidoxine: This drug is typically used alongside atropine for treating organophosphate poisoning to reactivate acetylcholinesterase, but it does not counteract the cholinergic symptoms the patient is experiencing.
  • • B) Atropine: This is the correct answer. The farmer's symptoms such as pinpoint pupils, excessive salivation, and bradycardia suggest cholinergic toxicity, likely from organophosphate exposure. Atropine acts as an antagonist at muscarinic cholinergic receptors and would counteract many of the symptoms observed.
  • • C) Physostigmine: This drug is a cholinesterase inhibitor and would worsen the symptoms of cholinergic toxicity, making it an inappropriate treatment in this case.
  • • D) N-acetylcysteine: This is commonly used for acetaminophen overdose and would not be effective for treating symptoms of cholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is scheduled to receive a new medication. The physician explains the mechanism of action and potential side effects of finasteride to the patient and his family. Which of the following is true about finasteride?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the production of testosterone.

options.label: B
options.text: It act as an antagonist of androgen receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: It can cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido and erectile dysfunction.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only effective in reducing symptoms of BPH in the short-term.

questions.correct_answer: C. It can cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido and erectile dysfunction.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. It can cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido and erectile dysfunction.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Finasteride like drugs are a class of medications used to treat BPH by reducing the size of the prostate gland. They work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha reductase, which converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). By reducing the levels of DHT, 5 alpha reductase inhibitors can shrink the prostate gland and improve urinary symptoms associated with BPH. A potential side effect of these medications is sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido and erectile dysfunction. These medications can take several months to achieve their maximum effect and can provide long-term relief of BPH symptoms.

questions.text: A 29-year-old researcher is studying a novel antiviral drug that has shown promise in in-vitro studies. The researcher is in the process of planning the clinical development of the drug. She explains to her team that the next step involves a phase zero clinical trial, which will be crucial in determining whether to move on to phase I trials. The team is confused, as they are not familiar with phase zero clinical trials. Which of the following statements is true regarding phase zero clinical trials, that would help the team understand its significance?

options.label: A
options.text: Phase zero clinical trials are typically conducted in animal models to assess the safety and efficacy of a new drug.

options.label: B
options.text: Phase zero clinical trials are comprehensive studies designed to provide conclusive data on the safety and efficacy of a new drug.

options.label: C
options.text: Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement of the drug in the human body.

options.label: D
options.text: Phase zero clinical trials are also known as therapeutic trials and aim to cure or mitigate symptoms of the disease in question.

questions.correct_answer: C. Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement of the drug in the human body.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement and metabolism of the drug in the human body.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Phase zero clinical trials are typically conducted in animal models to assess the safety and efficacy of a new drug: This statement is incorrect. Phase zero clinical trials are human trials that precede phase I trials. They are not animal studies.
  • • B) Phase zero clinical trials are comprehensive studies designed to provide conclusive data on the safety and efficacy of a new drug: This is incorrect. Phase zero trials are not designed to provide comprehensive data on safety and efficacy but are focused on pharmacokinetics and perhaps some initial pharmacodynamic data.
  • • C) Phase zero clinical trials primarily focus on pharmacokinetics, particularly on the movement of the drug in the human body: This is correct. The main aim of phase zero trials is to gather preliminary data on pharmacokinetics and assess whether the drug behaves in humans as it does in preclinical models.
  • • D) Phase zero clinical trials are also known as therapeutic trials and aim to cure or mitigate symptoms of the disease in question: This is incorrect. Phase zero trials are exploratory trials that precede phase I trials; they are not focused on therapeutic outcomes.
  • • Therefore, the statement that would best help the team understand the significance of phase zero trials is that they primarily focus on pharmacokinetics and provide initial human data on the movement and metabolism of the drug.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) consults his physician for treatment options. The physician recommends the use of rabeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor. Which of the following statements about proton pump inhibitors is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors are available as enteric-coated tablets.

options.label: B
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors are inactive at neutral pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors should be taken half an hour before food

questions.correct_answer: B. Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

Explanation:

  • • A) Proton pump inhibitors are available as enteric-coated tablets: This statement is TRUE. The enteric coating allows the medication to pass through the stomach without being destroyed by the stomach acid, eventually dissolving in the intestine for absorption.
  • • B) Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells: This statement is FALSE. Proton pump inhibitors, including rabeprazole, act from the acidic canaliculus inside the gastric parietal cell, not from the luminal side.
  • • C) Proton pump inhibitors are inactive at neutral pH: This statement is TRUE. Proton pump inhibitors are prodrugs that are activated in an acidic environment, which allows them to act specifically on the stomach's acid-secreting cells.
  • • D) Proton pump inhibitors should be taken half an hour before food: This statement is TRUE. Taking proton pump inhibitors around 30 minutes before eating ensures better activation of the drug, as the stomach starts producing acid in response to eating, thereby optimizing the drug's efficacy.
  • • Therefore, the statement that is INCORRECT regarding proton pump inhibitors is that they act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. He has been diagnosed with overactive bladder and his previous medication (oxybutynin) was not effective in managing his symptoms. Which of the following drugs is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist that may be effective in treating this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Vibegron

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Tolterodine: This drug is an antimuscarinic agent, not a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist. It is commonly used in the treatment of overactive bladder but works through a different mechanism of action than beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonists.
  • • B) Memantine: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of moderate-to-severe Alzheimer's disease. It has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder.
  • • C) Vibegron: This is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist (similar to mirabegron) that is used in the treatment of overactive bladder. By stimulating beta-3 adrenergic receptors in the detrusor muscle of the bladder, it relaxes the muscle and improves symptoms like urinary urgency and frequency.
  • • D) Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that is used to treat various types of seizures. It has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the emergency department for treatment of a drug overdose. The identity of the drug is unknown, but it is observed that when the urine pH is acidic, the renal clearance of the drug is less than GFR and that when the urine pH is alkaline, the clearance is greater than GFR. The drug probably is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Weak acid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When the urine pH is acidic, the renal clearance of a weak acid drug is less than the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This is because in acidic urine, weak acid drugs remain predominantly in their non-ionized form, which hinders their excretion into the urine. As a result, their renal clearance is limited.
  • • On the other hand, when the urine pH is alkaline, the renal clearance of a weak acid drug is greater than the GFR. In alkaline urine, weak acid drugs become ionized, which promotes their excretion into the urine. This leads to a higher renal clearance compared to the GFR.
  • • Strong acids (Choice A) and strong bases (Choice D) are usually fully ionized and do not undergo significant changes in their excretion based on urine pH.
  • • Therefore, based on the observed changes in renal clearance in response to urine pH, the drug in question is most likely a weak acid (Choice B).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pain is being managed on an oral pain medication. The healthcare team is monitoring the patient's response to medication and decides to take periodic plasma concentration samples. The team wants to evaluate the rate at which the drug is absorbed into the patient's system. Which of the following parameters on a plasma concentration vs. time graph would be most indicative of the rate of drug absorption for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Tmax

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • A) Area under the Curve (AUC): This parameter reflects the total drug exposure over time but does not give insights into the rate of drug absorption.
  • • B) Half-life (T1/2): This measures how long it takes for the drug concentration to decrease to half its initial value, more related to the elimination phase rather than the absorption rate.
  • • C) Maximum concentration (Cmax): This indicates the peak concentration of the drug in the bloodstream but doesn't specify how quickly this level is reached.
  • • D) Time to reach maximum concentration (Tmax): This is the time it takes for the drug to reach its peak concentration in the plasma. It gives an indication of how quickly the drug is absorbed into the system.
  • • Therefore, the time to reach maximum concentration (Tmax) is the best parameter to evaluate the rate of drug absorption.

Ans. A. Nivolumab works by blocking the PD-1 receptor and is used to treat various types of cancer.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Immune checkpoint inhibitors are a type of immunotherapy that work by releasing the brakes on the immune system, allowing it to attack cancer cells more effectively. Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks the PD-1 receptor on T cells, which prevents the inhibition of T cell activation and enhances the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. Nivolumab has been approved for the treatment of various types of cancer, including Hodgkin’s lymphoma, melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer, and kidney cancer. Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF that inhibits angiogenesis, the formation of new blood vessels, and is used to treat solid tumors. Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody against CD20 that depletes B cells and is used to treat lymphoma and autoimmune disorders. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor and is used to treat breast cancer.

questions.correct_answer: D. Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Zavegepant - CGRP receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks: This is a correct match. Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist. It is used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. CGRP is a neuropeptide that plays a role in the pathophysiology of migraines, and antagonists like Zavegepant block its activity, thereby alleviating symptoms.
  • • B) Pembrolizumab – Immune check point inhibitor used for endometrial carcinoma: This is also a correct match. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets the PD-1 receptor. It is used for a variety of cancers, including endometrial carcinoma, especially in cases that are MSI-H or dMMR (microsatellite instability-high or mismatch repair deficient).
  • • C) Ertugliflozin – SGLT2 inhibitor for treatment of diabetes mellitus: This is another correct match. Ertugliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, which is used to manage blood sugar levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, thereby leading to the excretion of glucose in the urine.
  • • D) Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity: This is the incorrect match. Ivabradine is indeed a "funny" current (If) blocker, but it is used for the treatment of certain types of chronic heart failure and angina pectoris (chest pain), not for treating decreased visual acuity.
  • • Therefore, option D is not a correct match concerning the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drug.

By decreasing the production of thromboxane A2, aspirin reduces the activation and aggregation of platelets, thereby preventing further clot formation. questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has recently completed a course of chemotherapy that included doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and paclitaxel. Shortly after her chemotherapy, she developed febrile neutropenia and was treated with filgrastim and cefepime. She also has a history of hypertension controlled with amlodipine. She now reports experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. An echocardiogram reveals her ejection fraction has decreased to 40%. What is the most likely drug-related cause of her reduced ejection fraction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Doxorubicin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Filgrastim: This drug is used to stimulate the production of neutrophils and is commonly used to treat febrile neutropenia. It is not generally associated with cardiomyopathy or a reduced ejection fraction.
  • • B) Doxorubicin: Doxorubicin is a chemotherapy agent known for its cardiotoxic effects, which can result in reduced ejection fraction and symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. Given the patient's recent chemotherapy regimen that included doxorubicin, this is the most likely cause of her decreased ejection fraction.
  • • C) Cefepime: This antibiotic is commonly used to treat bacterial infections, including those that may occur with febrile neutropenia. It is not typically associated with reduced ejection fraction or cardiomyopathy.
  • • D) Amlodipine: This drug is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension. While it has cardiovascular effects, it is not generally associated with a reduced ejection fraction or cardiomyopathy.

Ans. C. Varenicline is a partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor that is used to aid smoking cessation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Varenicline is a medication that is used to aid smoking cessation. questions.text: A 55-year-old man who received a kidney transplant three months ago is admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he exhibits right upper quadrant tenderness. Lab investigations reveal abnormal liver enzymes, and a blood culture returns positive for cytomegalovirus (CMV). questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Inhibition of calcineurin: Tacrolimus acts by inhibiting calcineurin, which plays a pivotal role in T-cell activation. This immunosuppressive action can make the patient susceptible to infections such as CMV.
  • • B) Blockade of IL-2 receptor: This is a mechanism of other immunosuppressive drugs like basiliximab but not tacrolimus. Therefore, it is not relevant to the patient's current condition.
  • • C) IMP dehydrogenase inhibition: This is the mechanism of mycophenolate mofetil, another immunosuppressive drug. It is not applicable to tacrolimus.
  • • D) Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase inhibition: This mechanism is associated with drugs like leflunomide but is not relevant to the action of tacrolimus.
  • • Thus, the primary pharmacological action of tacrolimus that might have predisposed this patient to develop a CMV infection is the inhibition of calcineurin.

questions.text: A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of osteoporosis is being evaluated for potential pharmacological treatments to strengthen her bones. She has tried lifestyle modifications, including weight-bearing exercises and calcium supplements, with limited improvement. Her physician is considering various pharmacological agents to inhibit osteoclastic activity and thereby prevent further bone loss. Which of the following medications does NOT primarily act by inhibiting osteoclasts?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Teriparatide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • a) Denosumab: This is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the RANKL (Receptor Activator for Nuclear Factor κ B Ligand), which is essential for the formation and function of osteoclasts. Thus, it inhibits osteoclast activity.
  • • b) Strontium ranelate: This drug is used in the treatment of osteoporosis and works by both promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption. It is thought to inhibit osteoclasts, although the exact mechanism is not well understood.
  • • c) Teriparatide: This is the correct answer. Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone. It is actually an anabolic (bone-building) agent that stimulates osteoblast activity, rather than inhibiting osteoclasts.
  • • d) Raloxifene: This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits bone resorption by osteoclasts, thus serving to preserve bone mass in conditions like osteoporosis.
  • • Teriparatide does not inhibit osteoclasts but stimulates osteoblasts, making it the correct answer for the drug that does not act by inhibiting osteoclasts.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.

  • • A) Additive diuretic effect of hydrochlorothiazide and lithium: While both hydrochlorothiazide and lithium can have diuretic effects, this option doesn't directly explain the elevated serum lithium level. The primary concern here is the elevated lithium level, not an additive diuretic effect.
  • • B) Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide can increase the renal reabsorption of lithium, leading to elevated serum lithium levels and symptoms of toxicity. This is the most likely explanation for the patient's elevated lithium level.
  • • C) Decreased gastrointestinal absorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide: This option is misleading because decreased gastrointestinal absorption of lithium would lead to lower serum lithium levels, not higher.
  • • D) Hydrochlorothiazide-induced enhancement of lithium metabolism: This is also a distractor. Enhancement of lithium metabolism would typically result in reduced serum lithium levels, not elevated levels.
  • • Therefore, the most likely cause for the elevated serum lithium level and symptoms in this patient is the increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.
